Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research in Undergraduate STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Dakota State University will conduct a summer research program to engage 30 undergraduate students in collaborative, interdisciplinary research in STEM Education. This project will foster collaboration through faculty and peer mentoring and cohort building activities. REU participants will learn qualitative and quantitative research methods, scientific communication skills, and become familiar with career paths in STEM Education. The ultimate goal of this project is to promote the matriculation of talented students to graduate programs in what is referred to as discipline-based education research (DBER). This project builds on a prior NSF award that has produced publishable results in the area of DBER.

Through this project REU students will be able to select from a wide variety of undergraduate research projects that pose important questions about the nature of assessment, reasoning, and the impact of learning assistants, crossing many STEM disciplines. The students will prepare for their research experience by reading and discussing assigned papers and participating in IRB training (both done online) before they arrive at the REU site. The benefit of this prior, virtual mentoring will be twofold; the students will receive essential training in education research, an area that may not be familiar to them and they will begin to build relationships with their research mentors. During the project the students will participate in a well-structured professional development seminar through which they will address ethical practices, careers in STEM, and pathways to graduate school. Formative evaluation will provide feedback necessary to refine the project each year through information gathered from entrance and exit surveys, the Survey of Undergraduate Research Experiences, the Experimental Design Ability Test, and interviews with students. Summative evaluation activities will include REU student exit interviews, an exit survey, and tracking of students' career trajectories through follow-up surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Growing Up STEM, hosted by North Dakota State University, is one of the first NSF-supported interdisciplinary REU programs focused on introducing undergraduates to research in STEM Education. Our program seeks to develop the whole student, supporting the development of research and professional skills, while attending to the health and well-being of all participants. In particular, our program goals included:

1. Providing participants with experience in DBER to facilitate informed decisions regarding career pathways and opportunities in DBER.

2. Enabling participants to develop hands-on and critical thinking skills to facilitate their engagement and future success in research.

3. Fostering an understanding and appreciation of the collaborative and collegial nature of research through participation in a collaborative research environment.

4. Encouraging participants to evaluate the implications of DBER research on teaching and learning in the undergraduate classroom.

5. Increasing participants’ science communication skills through dissemination of research via posters and oral presentations at local, regional, and national conferences.

 

Across the three years of our REU program, we supported 29 REU participants who developed and implemented independent research projects. Participants were mentored by eight STEM Edu faculty across disciplines of Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Physics. Kimi Booth (Biology), Jeff Boyer (College of Science and Mathematics), John Buncher (Physics), Lisa Montplaisir (Biology), William Martin (Math), James Nyachwaya (Chemistry), Jennifer Momsen (Biology), and Warren Christensen (Physics) served as faculty mentors during the three summers.

 

A primary goal of Growing Up STEM was to support participants’ development of research and professional skills. Each week, REU students participated in professional development workshops on establishing good research practices and habits, oral and poster presentations, CV development, understanding the graduate school experience, and more. Specific research skill development occurred through individual meetings with their mentor, lab meetings, and small-group discussions. Finally, students gained practical experiences through chalk talks and our end-of-program poster symposium.

 

A secondary goal of Growing Up STEM was to support the development of a community of practice, so that students felt included in our broader DBER community. We accomplished this goal by supporting the development of a cohort of scholars, who were housed together in campus apartments, worked in communal research spaces, and participated in organized social activities. REU participants were actively engaged in weekly lab meetings, which provided opportunities to develop analytical and presentation skills, alongside graduate students and postdocs. Outside of research, REU participants took part in a number of social events led by faculty, including a rib cooking festival, a local baseball game, a welcoming picnic, downtown street fair, and an end of program farewell BBQ.

The success of our program is measured by the success of our participants. Over the course of our program, 14 REU participants presented their research at National meetings, with two students earning awards for their posters at the 2018 AAAS meeting (Outstanding poster and honorable mention). Five students published a portion of their summer research.
